moves.5. d4: 5.d4!? This is some variation of the centre attack. I've never seen it ever being played. I think the idea is if 5. ... exd4 6. e5. This line shouldn't be too effective against Karpov.
moves.5... exd4 6. O-O Be7: This transposes into the centre attack. Black develops the dark squared bishop while breaking the pin on his king.
moves.7. e5: Attacks the knight and gains space.
moves.7... Ne4: Nice position for the knight. Since the E file is closed, the square isn't so bad.
moves.9. Nf5: Future threats on g7 and provoking d6 or g6.
moves.10... bxc6 11. Nxe7+ Qxe7 12. Re1: Black doesn't want to play Qxe5 because that just drops a knight after f3.
moves.12... Re8: This move is silent but deadly. It contains a little trap.
moves.13. f3: It's understandable that you want to chase the knight away and open the file up.
moves.13... Nd6: The knight is immune because if 14. exd6 qxe1+ 15. Qxe1 Rxe1+ 16. Kf2 Rxc1. Up a rook and in a winning position.
moves.14. b3 Nf5: Black has more active pieces. White is still cramped and struggling to develop.
moves.15. Ba3: Attacks the queen. This move isn't too effective as the e7 wasn't the best place for the queen. Better was probably Bb2. Nd2 is playable.
moves.15... Qg5 16. Bb2: 16. Bb2? A waste of time. He seems to know of blacks attack. Better here was Qd2 trying to exchange queens.
moves.17. Qd2: Offering the exchange of queens and protecting g2.
moves.17... f6 18. Qf2 Bh3: Attacks g2 a third time. Will whtie be able to withstand blacks attack?
moves.19. g4: Completely understandable. Now one attacker is gone.
moves.19... fxe5: Now black is a pawn up in a winning position.
moves.20. Nd2: Although white develops his knight this completely loses. Better was Nc3 or Qg3 or Qe3.
moves.20... Qxd2: Karpov finishes Junhke with a tactical shot. If 21. Qxd2, Black will win the queen baack with Nxf3 and then Nxd2. If white tries Nxh4 then Qg2# If any other move he's down a knight and a pawn and will have to survive an attack. Junhke was only an amateur at the time.
